events.name: Earthquake
events.description: (Earthquake)

events.name: 2nd emergency attitude was issued.
events.description: 2nd emergency attitude was announced. Contingency Planning Center was established (and combined with Emergency Center) (Emergency Attitude)

events.name: Admin Building evacuated to parking lot
events.description: Personnel in the administration building evacuated to the parking lot in front of the building and called over the names. Emergency response personnel stationed in the Anti-Seismic Building (TSC Building) and started response. Everyone was familiar with evacuation route because emergency drill was done just a week before the earthquake. (Evacuation)

events.name: Frequent evacuation/suspension of field work
events.description: Frequent evacuation and suspension of field work due to continued tsunami alerts and aftershocks. Working without lighting and communication measures and significant amount of debris and soil by the tsunami made the field operation very difficult. (Evacuation)

events.name: Evacuation - 2 km
events.description: Fukushima prefecture ordered the residents within 2km radius of the periphery of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station to evacuate. An evacuation order is issued by the government to persons within a radius of 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) from the Fukushima I station. Those within a radius of 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) are told that they can remain in their homes, and carry on with regular activities, until told otherwise. TEPCO announces that the pressure inside reactor unit 1 of Fukushima I is more than twice normal levels. (Evacuation)

events.name: Evacuation - 3 km
events.description: Prime Minister ordered the residents within 3km radius of the periphery of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station to evacuate, and the residents within 3km to 10km radius of the periphery to evacuate indoors. Authorities apparently wanted to "limit the size of costly and disruptive evacuations in land-scarce Japan and to avoid public questioning of the politically powerful nuclear industry". There has been public anger about an "official campaign to play down the scope of the accident and the potential health risks". (Evacuation)

events.name: Evacuation - 10 km
events.description: Prime Minister ordered the residents 10km radius of the periphery of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station. (Evacuation)

events.name: PSER updated Okuma still not evacuated
events.description: At 8:27 AM, TEPCO employees dispatched to Okuma town office reported to PSER that part of Okuma town hadnâ€t yet evacuated. (Evacuation)

events.name: Confirmed Kuma area and Okuma evacuations complete
events.description: At 9:03 AM - we confirmed that Kuma area, Okuma town finished evacuation. We notified Fukushima prefecture that we will make announcement to the media and do Vent at 9:05 AM. (Evacuation)

events.name: Workers evacuated, rescued and transported the injured
events.description: At 15:36, Reactor 1 reactor building exploded. Workers at the field evacuated, rescued and transported the injured. (TEPCO: 3, Contractor: 2) To verify safety and see effect of the explosion, field survey and walk down were conducted. (Status of fire engines, damages to the buildings and smoking etc.) Fire engines maintained their function though windshield was broken. As for the SLC pump, ballistic fragments by the explosion damaged cable damaged the cable and high-voltage power supply vehicle stopped automatically. The hoses prepared for seawater injection was also damaged. It was impossible to resume restoration work until evacuation, confirmation of the safety of workers and the field were completed. Workers removed debris, collected hoses from outdoor fire hydrants and laid hoses again to seawater injection. Because the debris near Reactor 1 had high radiation, all these activities were monitored by radioactive protection technicians. (Evacuation)

events.name: Evacuation within 20 km radius
events.description: (Evacuation)

events.name: Prime Minister ordered 20-30km radius seek indoor shelter
events.description: Prime Minister ordered the residents 20km to 30km radius of the periphery of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station to evacuate. (Evacuation)

events.name: Workers evacuated to Main Anti-Earthquake Building
events.description: At 3/14 11:01 - due to the explosion of reactor building of Reactor 3, to secure safety all the workers evacuated from site. Hose piping was ready to use but were unavailable to use due to the damage of fire engines and hose pipe. Workers except for operators in Main Control Room interrupted their work and evacuated to Main Anti-Earthquake Building. We could not resume restoration work for a while since it took time for us to confirm workersâ€ safety and the situation of the site. 4 TEPCO employees, 3 workers of partner companies and 4 persons of Self Defense Force got injured. Rubbles with high level of radioactivity were scattered around by the explosion. Seawater injection was stopped since fire engines and hoses got damaged. Due to the rubbles the vertical shaft of reversing valve became unusable. (Evacuation)

events.name: Reported evacuation of employees to Fukushima Daini
events.description: It was informed to the government offices etc. that the employees except for the needed personnel for the monitoring and the operation would evacuate temporally to the Fukushima Daini Nuclear Power Station (Evacuation)

events.name: Reactor 1 Explosion
events.description: Reactor 1 exploded and debris by the explosion hit and damaged the cable, then the high voltage power supply vehicle automatically stopped. Field work was suspended and everyone evacuated to Anti-Seismic Building (TSC Building). An explosion occurred in the reactor building. Power- supply facility for the standby liquid control system and pre-arranged hose for seawater injection were damaged and out of commission. (Explosion)

events.name: Explosion at Reactor 3
events.description: An explosion occurred in the reactor building. Injection of sea water stooped as the fire truck and hose were damaged (Explosion)

events.name: Prime Minister Kan Arrives
events.description: Prime Minister arrived at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station (Kan Arrives)

events.name: Prime Minster Kan Departs
events.description: Prime Minister departed from Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station (Kan Departs)

events.name: Events in Main Control Room of Reactors 1-2
events.description: Main Control Room of Reactor 1-2 Operators started normal scram response after the shaking trailed off. Shift Supervisor confirmed scram of the units and supervised response in between the Reactor 1 and 2 control panels. Each operator was assigned to control panels and Chief Operator conducted monitoring and operation, also reported plant situation to Shift Supervisor. At 14:52, operators confirmed automatic start up of the Isolation Condenser (IC) at Reactor 1. Because reactor water stayed in normal level, operators decided to use HPCI when water level dropped and to control reactor pressure by IC. At 15:03, reactor pressure of Reactor 1 dropped so fast and the reactor coolant temperature decreased 55 C per hour, exceeding a criteria in the Tech.Spec. Then operators closed MO-3A and 3B, return isolation valves of IC. IC was in stand-by condition with other valves in the IC remained open. Operators judged that only one train of IC was sufficient to control the reactor pressure in 6 â€“ 7 MPa. They decided to use Train A and started to control the pressure by operating MO-3A. As for Reactor 2, RCIC was started manually but tripped because of high reactor water level. After that, RCIC was started manually again. (Main Control Room Events)

events.name: Events in Main Control Room of Reactors 3-4
events.description: Main Control Room of Reactor 3-4 MCR became white as if laid a smoke screen by dust caused by the earthquake. After the shaking was trailed off, operators started normal scram response. Shift Supervisor reported plant scrams. Emergency Diesel Generator (DG) started up due to loss of off-site power. Emergency bus was confirmed to be charged by DG. At Reactor 3, RCIC was manually started but tripped by high reactor water level. After the earthquake, safety of the operators was checked. Earthquake and Tsunami alert were paged to the plant workers. (Main Control Room Events)

events.name: Events in Main Control Room of Reactors 5-6
events.description: Main Control Room of Reactor 5-6 Shift Supervisor were checking control panel at his desk and securing his safety until the shaking trailed off. Other operators also secured their safety at the same time paid attention to monitoring panels. After the shaking, operators checked alarms. Most of the alarms was sounding at that time. Since Paging and ITV were unavailable, PHS (Personal Handy phone System: like cell phone) was utilized to order evacuation for field workers. Shift operators returned to the MCR after gathered in anteroom. (Main Control Room Events)

events.name: Situation at Main Control Room of Reactor 1-2
events.description: Lighting and indicators in the MCR gradually fading due to loss of all AC power. Sound of alarm was lost, too. In Reactor 1-side of MCR, only emergency lights remained. In Reactor 2- side, all lighting was lost and it became completely dark. By command of Shift Supervisor, operators checked availability of equipment in MCR. For Reactor 1 IC and HPCI were operable by DC power. However, valve status of IC was not indicated on the control panel. Operators judged HPCI was not operable because indicators on the control panel were gradually faded. For Reactor 2, operating status of RCIC became unknown. (Main Control Room Events)

events.name: Situation at Main Control Room of Reactor 3-4
events.description: Due to loss of all AC power, lighting in MCR was emergency light only. Since Reactor 4 was in refueling outage and completely defueled, parameters such as reactor water level was checked mainly focused at Reactor 3. This was conducted with flashlights. Peroperating procedure at the time of loss of AC power, unnecessary load was cut to extend battery life for RCIC and HPCI. (Main Control Room Events)

events.name: Situation at Main Control Room of Reactor 5-6
events.description: Two DGs at Reactor 5 and two DGs at Reactor 6 were stopped simultaneously by the tsunami. One remained DG at Reactor 6 continued operation with adjusting frequency. MCR at Reactor 5 lost lighting and emergency lights put on, but these emergency lights faded gradually then MCR became dark. MCR at Reactor 6 was same as normal. (Main Control Room Events)

events.name: SCRAM
events.description: Automatic Reactor scram, Stopped automatically Main Turbine, Started Emergency generator automatically. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reactor 1 IC started automatically
events.description: The isolation condenser (hereafter referred as IC) started automatically (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reactor 1 Subcritical
events.description: Subcritical state of reactor was confirmed (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reactor 1 IC suspended
events.description: IC was suspended manually to control the reactor pressure. The control of the reactor pressure by IC was started. (Reactor 1)

events.name: AC Power Lost
events.description: All the alternating-current sources were stopped. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Working to restore indicators in Main Control Room
events.description: Onsite workers were endeavoring to restore indicators in the Main Control Room. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reactor water level and status of water injection not confirmed
events.description: It was decided that a specific incident (impossibility of water injection by Emergency Core Cooling System) stipulated in article 15, clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness has occurred, because the reactor water level and the status of water injection was not confirmed. Judged that the specific issue (Enable to inject water by Emergency Core Cooling System) based on the article 15, clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness occurred because of enable to confirm Reactor water level and situation of injecting water. Reported it to authority etc. at 4:45 pm. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Submitted AM operation procedure to chief operator
events.description: At the Main Control Room we submitted the accident management (â€AMâ€?) operation procedure to the chief operator and confirmed the procedure. Also, we began confirming the name and place of valves required for opening the vent valves (â€Ventâ€?) using the checklist for valves. Generation team of Power station emergency response headquarters (â€PSERâ€?) began reviewing the AM operation procedure and checking the Vent procedures without electricity. Restoration team of PSER, during aftershocks, went to the administration main building (entrance prohibited) to get drawings in order to check the model and structure of the S/C vent valve (AO valve) required for Vent and open manually. At the same time, we inquired our subcontractors. From the drawings, we confirmed that there is a handle on the small valve of S/C vent valve (AO valve) and could be opened manually. We notified the Main Control Room accordingly. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Cancelled Reactor 1 ECCS Incident
events.description: It was decided to cancel a specific incident (impossibility of water injection by Emergency Core Cooling System) stipulated in article 15, clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness, because the reactor water level was confirmed. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reactor 1 - ECCS Impossible - Reactor water level and status of water injection not confirmed
events.description: It was decided that a specific incident (impossibility of water injection by Emergency Core Cooling System) stipulated in article 15, clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness has occurred, because the reactor water level was not confirmed again. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Discuss using alternative water injection
events.description: Site emergency response headquarters started to discuss using the alternative water injection which was put in place as an accident management measures (AM) and the fire protection tanks and fire engines deployed after Niigataken Chuetsuoki Earthquake. General Manager of Power station directed to start consideration of measure to injecting water to Reactor using the Fire Protection System which is installed as a measure for accident management and fire fighter. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirm water injection into reactor
events.description: At 17:12, the site emergency response headquarters started to discuss using the alternative water injection which was put in place as an accident management measures (AM) and the fire protection tanks and fire engines deployed after Niigataken Chuetsuoki Earthquake. Meanwhile, operators checked measures for alternative water injection with AM procedure in the MCR and confirmed injection line to RPV then started to use Diesel Driven Fire Pump (D/D FP). Operators lined up alternative water injection with D/D FP and Fire Protection line via Core Spray System , opening valves in the Core Spray lines by hand in the dark reactor building. After depressurize the RPV below 0.69 MPa, water injection through FP/CS became available. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Power supply unable to use
events.description: At 17:30, D/D FP started up but in stand-by. The restoration team of the site emergency response headquarters conducted visual inspections for inundation status and damages on exterior and insulation resistance tests were conducted on the power panels (M/C and P/C) and found power supply equipment in Reactor 1 was unable to use but one of P/Cs in Reactor 2 was operable. The team made plans to use SLC (Stand by Liquid Control) system to inject water in the RPV, since the SLC had high discharge pressure. Power supply for the SLC was planned to be restored by power supply vehicle via P/C in Reactor 2. Monitoring instruments in the MCR were unable to use because of power outage. Then an operator entered in the dark reactor building and confirmed the reactor pressure was 6.9 MPa as of 20:07. Later, water level indicator returned its function and indicated the level was 200 mm above TAF (Top of Active Fuel) at 21:19. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed steam rising out.
events.description: Operated to open IC return line of isolation valve (MO-3A) and IC steam line of isolation valve (MO-2A). Confirmed steam rising out. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Valves Closed
events.description: In MCR, operators found indication light of MO-3A and MO-2A after temporary restoration of DC power. The indicators showed the valves were closed. Then an operator opened the valves at 18:18 and confirmed the light indicated the valve status from close to open. Also steam generation was confirmed after the valve operation. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Closed Return Line Isolation Valve
events.description: At 18:25, the operator closed the return line isolation valve (MO-3A). (Reactor 1)

events.name: MCR Monitoring Instruments out of use
events.description: Monitoring instruments in the MCR were unable to use because of power outage. Then an operator entered in the dark reactor building and confirmed the reactor pressure was 6.9 MPa as of 20:07 (Reactor 1)

events.name: Temporary Lighting Turned On
events.description: Temporary lighting was turned on in the main control room. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Water level indicator returned its function
events.description: Water level indicator returned its function and indicated the level was 200 mm above TAF (Top of Active Fuel) at 21:19 (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirm water levels in Reactor 1
events.description: Reactor water levels were become clear for Reactor 1 - water level indicator returned its function and indicated the level was 200 mm above TAF (Top of Active Fuel) Water level in the reactor found out. Top of active fuel (hereinafter â€TAFâ€?) +200mm (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed steam rising out.
events.description: Operated to open IC return line of isolation valve (MO-3A). Confirmed steam rising out. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Prohibited entry to R/B.
events.description: 9:51 PMïŒThe dose at the R/B began to increase. We prohibited entry to R/B. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Radiation by ADP at R/B
events.description: 10:00 PM, PSER have been reported that the figures by APD went up to 0.8mSv during a very short period of time at the R/B. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed water level was TAF +550
events.description: Confirmed water level in the reactor was TAF+550 mm. Reported it to the authorities at 10:20 pm. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirm increase of radiation dose in T/B
events.description: 11:00 PM - Because of the influence of increase of dose at R/B, the radiation dose in the T/B increased. (in front of the airlock, north side, 1FL, T/B: 1.2mSv/h - n front of the airlock, south side, 1FL, T/B: 0.5mSv/h) (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reported 600 kPa abs to PSER
events.description: 11:50PM, at the Main Control Room, Restoration team of PSER connected the battery for the reactor water level gauge to D/W pressure gauge to check the pressure. The pressure indicated was 600kPa abs. Reported that to PSER. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Connected battery to D/W pressure gauge and took 600kPa abs reading
events.description: At the Main Control Room, Restoration team of PSER connected the battery for the reactor water level gauge to D/W pressure gauge to check the pressure. The pressure indicated was 600kPa abs. Reported that to PSER. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Prepare to vent PCF as D/W pressure likely to exceed 600kPa abs
events.description: The General Manager of power station instructed to prepare to vent the Primary Containment Vessel (hereinafter the Vent) as the drywell (hereinafter D/W) pressure was likely to exceed 600kPa abs and there was a possibility to implement the Vent. (Reactor 1)

events.name: D/W pressure increase
events.description: As D/W pressure was likely to exceed 600kPa abs, it was judged to a specific incident (extraordinary increase of pressure in the Primary Containment Vessel) occurred, based on Article 15, clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Asked authorities for and Agreed to vent at Reactor 1 and Reactor 2
events.description: Proposed and obtained agreement to implement the Vent at Reactor 1 and Unit2 to prime minister, minister of economy, trade and industry and Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency. At 1:30 AM, we asked for permission to do Vent to Prime Minister, Minister of METI and NISA and got approval. From Headquarters Task Force (HTF), we received instruction We would like you to do Vent by whatever ways to operate the MO valve and AO valve. At 3:00 AM, Minister of METI and we will announce doing Vent. After the announcement, please do Vent. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Diesel Fire Pump found stopped due to defects unable to restore
events.description: At 1:48, an Operator found D/D FP was stopped which had been on stand by to inject water into the RPV. In order to start the D/D FP again, diesel fuel was carried to the pump and fueled manually and batteries stored at an office of on-site contractor was carried and replaced but the pump did not work. (Reactor 1)

events.name: PSER sets 17 minute work time due to atmospheric radiation of 300 mSv/h
events.description: PSER received the evaluation result of work time at the field site to do Vent. If the atmospheric radiation is 300mSv/h, we have 17 minutes of work time under the radiation limit for emergency response (100mSv/h) (the air in the self-contained breathing apparatus lasts 20 minutes. Need to take iodine tablets.) (Reactor 1)

events.name: D/W pressure reached 840kPa abs
events.description: D/W pressure reached 840kPa absïŒthe maximum operation pressure = 427kPa gaugeâ€»ïŒ‰ â€»528.3kPa absïŒïŒ?427kPa gageïŒ‹101.3kPaïŒ‰ (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reactor pressure 0.8 MPa
events.description: Reactor pressure was 0.8 MPa at 2:4 (Reactor 1)

events.name: Vent Reactor 1
events.description: At 2:55 AM, on March 12, we could confirm operation of RCIC. We decided to prioritize opening the vent valve (â€Ventâ€?) for Reactor 1. We proceeded with Vent of Reactor 1. At the same time, we continued monitoring parameters of Reactor 2. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Opened airlock to R/B
events.description: HTF made the evaluation on exposure dose at the surrounding areas at the time of Vent and shared with the power station. At the power station, in order to measure dose in the R/B, we opened the airlock. As we saw white gaseous substance, we instantaneously closed the airlock. We couldnâ€t conduct dose measurement. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Found white gas substance in R/B airlock
events.description: HTF made the evaluation on exposure dose at the surrounding areas at the time of Vent and shared with the power station. At the power station, in order to measure dose in the R/B, we opened the airlock. As we saw white gaseous substance, we instantaneously closed the airlock. We couldnâ€t conduct dose measurement. At the Main Control Room, in preparation for Vent, we repeatedly confirmed the sequence of operation of valves, location of valves in Torus Room, height of valves etc. We collected as many equipments as possible required for the work. Those are fire fighting garments, self-contained breathing apparatus, APD, survey meter and flashlights. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Operations stopped at field site
events.description: At 4:30 AM, because of the risk of tsunami by aftershocks, PSER instructed the Main Control Room to prohibit operation at the field site. (Reactor 1)

events.name: APDs and full face masks delivered to Main Control Room
events.description: At 4:45 AM, PSER delivered APDs (set at 100mSv) and full face masks to the Main Control Room. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Contaminated worker returns to anti-earthquake building
events.description: When a worker returned to the main anti-earthquake building was contaminated, we decided to equip, from the entrance of the main anti-earthquake building, full face mask + charcoal filter + B garment, C garment or coverall when we go to the field site. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Ordered Radioactive Gear Worn
events.description: At 4:50 AM, as the worker returned to the main anti-earthquake building was contaminated, we decided to equip, from the entrance of the main anti-earthquake building, â€full face mask + charcoal filter + B garment, C garment or coverallâ€? when we go to the field site (Reactor 1)

events.name: Main Control Room was instructed to wear full face mask + charcoal filter + B garment and move to Reactor 2 side
events.description: When a worker returned to the main anti-earthquake building was contaminated, we decided to equip, from the entrance of the main anti-earthquake building, full face mask + charcoal filter + B garment, C garment or coverall when we go to the field site. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Additional fire engine arrives to site
events.description: A fire engine in the garage moved to Reactor 1. At first, the fire engine pumped up water at the fire protection tank then drove close to the reactor building and injected water through FP line, this operation was repeated because it was considered the elevation at the fire protection tank was too low and the discharge pressure of the pump in the fire engine was not enough. It took significant amount of time to drive the fire engine carefully under the half-collapsed building. It took time to go back and forth the fire engine between the fire protection tank and the reactor building, after some trial and error, continuous water injection started by using a horse equipped on the fire engine to directly connect the fire protection tank and the fire protection line to the RPV. Additional fire engine arrived to the site and this one was used to transport freshwater from the fire protection tank at Reactor 3 to the fire protection tank at Reactor 1 repeatedly. The fire protection tank had room for only one horse, so water injection to the RPV had to be suspended when the second fire engine came to replenish the water in the tank. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed planned evacuation from Okuma to Miyakoji
events.description: At 6:33 AMïŒas to the status of evacuation at surrounding areas, we confirmed that residents are planning to move from Okuma town to Miyakoji. (Reactor 1)

events.name: METI order to manual Vent
events.description: There was an order of The Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry to implement the Vent based on the laws and ordinances (manual Vent). (Reactor 1)

events.name: 3 two-person teams formed
events.description: At the Main Control Room, we formed three teams, two persons for each (Chief shift operator and deputy chief shift operator) because of the following reasons: (i) it is impossible to work by one person because of complete darkness (ii) the high anticipated dose and (iii) may need to return because of the aftershock. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Station Chief instructed to target 9 AM Vent of Reactor 1
events.description: The General Manager of the power station instructed to aim to implement the Vent at 9 am. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed evacuation status
events.description: 8:03 AM, Station Chief instructed to target 9 AM to do Vent for Reactor 1. At the Main Control Room, we formed three teams, two persons for each (Chief shift operator and deputy chief shift operator) because of the following reasons: (i) it is impossible to work by one person because of complete darkness (ii) the high anticipated dose and (iii) may need to return because of the aftershock. We confirmed the status of evacuation by residents (Reactor 1)

events.name: Coordinated with Fukushima Prefecture with to vent after evacuation over
events.description: At 8:37 we notified Fukushima prefecture that we are preparing for the commencement of Vent from 9:00 AM. We coordinated to Vent after evacuation is over. (Reactor 1)

events.name: First team departed to open the PCV vent valve
events.description: At 9:04 in order to open PCV vent valve, two shift operators went to the field site. They were equipped with fire fighting garment, self-contained breathing apparatus and APD. As the electricity was lost, the field sites in R/B and T/B were in complete darkness. They departed with flashlights. As there was no communication channel with the field site, we decided to dispatch teams to the field site one by one. After one team returned to the Main Control Room, the next team departed. The first team departed the Main Control Room to the field site to open the PCV vent valve (MO valve). (Reactor 1)

events.name: Announced Vent implementation
events.description: Announcement of implementation of the Vent (Reactor 1)

events.name: Opened to 25% - Exposure dose was 25 mSv
events.description: At 9:15 AM, opened to 25% per the operation procedure and returned to the Main Control Room. The exposure dose was 25mSv. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Manually opened MO vent valve of PCV
events.description: Manually opened the vent valve (MO valve) of Primary Containment Vessel (hereinafter â€?PCVâ€?) (Reactor 1)

events.name: Team 2 departs MCR to Torus Room - dose increased and risk of exceeding the dose limit (100 mSv)
events.description: At 9:24 AM, in order to open the S/C vent valve (AO valve) â€“ small, team 2 departed the Main Control Room to Torus Room. During the way, dose increased and as there was a risk to exceed the dose limit, 100mSv, (Reactor 1)

events.name: Gave up operation of vent valve of suppression chamber due to high radiation
events.description: An operation of the vent valve (A/O valve) of the suppression chamber (hereinafter S/C) was tried but given up due to high radioactive dose. As we could not open the S/C vent valve (AO valve) â€“ small at the field site, the PSER began considering the location to connect the temporary air compressor (to 11:00 AM). Also, PSER instructed the Main Control Room to open the S/C vent valve (AO valve) â€“ small by remote operation hoping for the residual air pressure in the I&C compressed air line. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Team 2 returns to MCR - Gave up work by Team 3
events.description: Team returned to the Main Control Room. As the dose was high, we gave up the work by team 3. We reported to the PSER. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reported failure to open A/O valve and increased radiation dose to PSER
events.description: At 9:30 AM, team returned to the Main Control Room. As the dose was high, we gave up the work by team 3. We reported to the PSER. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Did first remote opening
events.description: did the first remote opening, uncertain whether the valve opened. (Reactor 1)

events.name: S/C vent valve opened in central control room
events.description: S/C vent valve (AO valve) was opened in the central control room (with expectation of residual pressure of instrumentation air system). (Reactor 1)

events.name: Uncertain whether first remote opening opened valve
events.description: At 10:17 AM did the first remote opening, uncertain whether the valve opened. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Did second remote opening
events.description: Did the second remote opening, uncertain whether the valve opened. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Uncertain whether second remote opening opened valve
events.description: At 10:23 AMïŒdid the second remote opening, uncertain whether the valve opened. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Did third remote opening
events.description: Did the third remote opening, uncertain whether the valve opened. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Uncertain whether third remote operating worked
events.description: At 10:24 AMïŒdid the third remote opening, uncertain whether the valve opened. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed dose at main gate and MP became higher due to radiation released by vent
events.description: At 10:40 AM, as we confirmed that the dose at the main gate and MP became higher, PSER determined that it was highly likely that radioactive substances were released by Vent. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Could not open the S/C Vent valve (AO valve)
events.description: As we could not open the S/C vent valve (AO valve) â€“ small at the field site, the PSER began considering the location to connect the temporary air compressor (to 11:00 AM). Also, PSER instructed the Main Control Room to open the S/C vent valve (AO valve) â€“ small by remote operation hoping for the residual air pressure in the I&C compressed air line. (Reactor 1)

events.name: PSER looked for temporary compressor
events.description: The restoration team of PSER looked for the temporary compressor, received info that the there was one at the subcontractorâ€s office and decided to go and search at there. In order to connect the temporary compressor, we needed the adaptor. By using the piping and instrumentation diagrams, we decided the place to connect. At the field site, we took photos of that place and returned to PSER. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed Vent was not fully effective
events.description: At 11:15 AM, as the dose became lower, PSER suspected that the Vent was insufficient. Confirmed that there was a possibility that the Vent was not fully effective as the radioactive dose decreased (Reactor 1)

events.name: Reconfirmed actual procedures as how to operate valves and sequnces
events.description: At the Main Control Room we put together the piping and instrumentation diagrams, AM procedure manual, documents such as the drawings of valves and the whiteboard. We began confirming the actual procedures such as how to operate the valve and sequences. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Looked for adaptor
events.description: At 12:30 PM, we looked for the adaptor. We found the temporary compressor at our subcontractorâ€s office and transferred that by a crane truck. As the dose was high, we located the compressor at the outside of large equipments carry-in opening. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Started temporary compressor
events.description: At 2:00 PM, we started the temporary compressor (Reactor 1)

events.name: Confirmed D/W pressure went down determined release of radioactive substances
events.description: We confirmed that D/W pressure went down and determined this as release of radioactive substances by Vent. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Setup makeshift air compressor to operate S/C vent valve
events.description: When setting up a makeshift air compressor around 2 pm in order to operate the S/C vent valve (AO valve), we confirmed that the D/W pressure decreased and judged that the release of radioactive materials occurred by the Vent. We reported this information to the authorities at 3:18 pm. (Reactor 1)

events.name: D/W pressure decrease
events.description: D/W pressure 0.75MPa 0.58MPa(2:50 PM) (Reactor 1)

events.name: 80 tons of fresh water injected to RPV
events.description: At 14:53, 80,000 Litter of fresh water had been injected to the RPV. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Freshwater in fire protection tank drying up
events.description: Site Vice President directed to prepare for seawater injection to the RPV. Since freshwater in the fire protection tank at Reactor 1 was drying up, freshwater was transported from other fire protection tanks in a quick pace and preparation for seawater injection was moved ahead. (Reactor 1)

events.name: VP directed to prepare for seawater injection to RPV
events.description: At 14:54, Site Vice President directed to prepare for seawater injection to the RPV. Since freshwater in the fire protection tank at Reactor 1 was drying up, freshwater was transported from other fire protection tanks in a quick pace and preparation for seawater injection was moved ahead. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Installed cables damaged by explosion at Reactor 1
events.description: At around 15:30, though cable was connected to the primary side of the P/C of Reactor 2 and, in parallel, connection was made between high voltage power supple vehicle, at 15:36 explosion occurred at Reactor 1. Installed cables were damaged by explosion litter and high voltage poser supply vehicle was tripped. All the workers stopped their work and evacuated to the Main Anti-Earthquake Building. On the next day, tried restart of power supply vehicle, which was connected to power center of Reactor 2, however, current surge relay was operated and failed to supply power. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Seawater taken from backwash pit at Reactor 3
events.description: Around 15:30, cable connection between the primary side of P/C at Reactor 2 and high-voltage power supply vehicle was completed. Power was supplied just short of the SLC pump. Lining up of seawater injection was completed with three fire engines connected in series to have sufficient head. Seawater was taken from the backwash pit at Reactor 3. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Prepared boric-acid for injection after power restored
events.description: All the preparations were complete for the injection of boric-acid solution through the standby liquid control system, upon power restoration by use of a power supply car. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Seawater injection by fire engines started
events.description: At 19:04, seawater injection started using the fire protection line and fire engines. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Boric acid mixed with seawater and injected into reactor
events.description: Boric-acid solution was started to be mixed with seawater and injected into the reactor. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Fire hydrant damaged - Obstacles for fire engines
events.description: It was impossible to use filtered water as water source for RPV because fire hydrant was damaged and water was spewed. To have sufficient amount of filtered water for the injection, valves were closed around the area. Also other water sources were looked for and the fire protection tank was confirmed to be available. One fire engine was made ready for injection to the RPV. Other two fire engines were unavailable, for one was failed by the tsunami and the other was not able to move from the area near Reactor 5/6. Damages on the road and debris by the tsunami divided the access route between Units 1 â€“ 4 side and Units 5,6 side. There were a lot of obstacles to deploy the available fire engine close to Reactor 1. Tank swept by the tsunami blocked a road in front of the old-administration building and the road was impassable. The gate at the physical protection headquarters lost power and did not open. The restoration team of the site emergency response headquarters looked for rout in the site, then got access for the fire engine by breaking a lock at the gate between Units 2 and 3. As for the fire engine, measures were studied to inject water via Fire Protection line. Also additional fire engines and water transportation by the SDF were considered. Reactor pressure was 0.8 MPa at 2:40 (Reactor 1)

events.name: Preparation for seawater injection
events.description: Because of the limitation of the amount of freshwater in the fire protection tanks, preparation for seawater injection was initiated. Instead of taking seawater directly from the sea, the backwash pit where seawater was filled by the tsunami was selected as a supply source taking the road conditions in the site and distance from Reactor 1 into consideration. (Reactor 1)

events.name: PSER takes photos of piping and instrumentation diagrams
events.description: The restoration team of PSER looked for the temporary compressor, received info that the there was one at the subcontractorâ€s office and decided to go and search at there. In order to connect the temporary compressor, we needed the adaptor. By using the piping and instrumentation diagrams, we decided the place to connect. At the field site, we took photos of that place and returned to PSER. (Reactor 1)

events.name: SLC power restored by power supply vehicle
events.description: Power supply and pump in SLC system were not affected by the tsunami. Since the SLC has high-head pump, power supply was being restored by the power supply vehicle. (Reactor 1)

events.name: Power Supply Vehicles dispatched to Fukushima Daiichi
events.description: Corporate Distribution Department ordered branch offices to secure high and low voltage power supply vehicles and confirm driving route to Fukushima Diichi NPS. Although high and low voltage power supply vehicles headed to Fukushima Daiichi they were not able to drive up to the site fast enough because of damages of roads and traffic jam. It was considered to transport the power supply vehicles by choppers of the Self Defense Force, but it turned out that the weight of the vehicles were too heavy to carry. TEPCO requested Tohoku Electric Power Company to dispatch power supply vehicles to Fukushima Daiichi NPS. (Reactor 1, Reactor 2)

events.name: Restoration team gathers batteries and cables
events.description: The restoration team in the site emergency response headquarters prepared for necessary documents and drawings to restore power in MCRs. Also they started to gather batteries and cables at offices of contractorâ€s office in the site. The team carried batteries and cables which were collected in the site to MCR of Reactor 1/2. Then confirming drawings, they started to connect the batteries to instrument panel in the MCR. At the event of â€ECCS was unavailable to inject water into the reactorâ€?, a top priority was to understand the status of water injection into the RPV. So restoration work was focused on connecting batteries to reactor water indicator which functions by DC power. (Reactor 1, Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 1-2 instrumentation power lost
events.description: At 15:50, instrumentation power was lost and reactor water levels for Units 1 and 2 became unknown. Communication between MCR and the site emergency response headquarters was limited to a hot-line and fixed-line phone, it was not able to use PHS. (Reactor 1, Reactor 2)

events.name: Press conference about the Vent implementation was held.
events.description: Press conference about the Vent implementation was held. (Reactor 1, Reactor 2)

events.name: Loss of all on-site AC electric supply
events.description: It was determined that a specific incident stipulated in article 10,clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness (loss of all AC electric supply) occurred in Units 1 through 5 and it was reported to the government offices etc. (Reactor 1, Reactor 2, Reactor 3, Reactor 4, Reactor 5)

events.name: Headquarters for major disaster countermeasures established
events.description: Headquarter for major disaster countermeasures was established in the head office to grasp situations of damages and to restore the outage due to the earthquake. Emergency Center was established at the head office (Recognizing the degree of damages caused by the earthquake, restoring blackouts) Set up an Emergency Center at headquarter.(To figure out the situation by damage caused by earthquake, recovering from blackout etc) (Reactor 1, Reactor 2, Reactor 3, Reactor 4, Reactor 5, Reactor 6)

events.name: Government confirms evacuation of 3km radius
events.description: Government confirmed the completion of evacuation of the residents (3km radius of the periphery of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station in Futaba Town and Okuma Town, reconfirmed at 1:45 am) (Reactor 1, Reactor 2, Reactor 3, Reactor 4, Reactor 5, Reactor 6)

events.name: Government reconfirms evacuation of 3km radius
events.description: (3km radius of the periphery of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station in Futaba Town and Okuma Town, reconfirmed at 1:45 am) (Reactor 1, Reactor 2, Reactor 3, Reactor 4, Reactor 5, Reactor 6)

events.name: SCRAM
events.description: Automatic Reactor scram, Stopped automatically Main Turbine, Started Emergency generator automatically. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor water level (Top of Active Fuel +3400mm).
events.description: Reactor water levels were become clear for Reactor 2 Reactor water level (Top of Active Fuel +3400mm). As a result of restoration work of instruments, at 9:50 PM, we could confirm the Reactor water level (Top of Active Fuel +3400mm). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Operator confirms water puddle in RCIC
events.description: In the early morning of March 12, an operator confirmed operating status at the field (RCIC Room). The operator was equipped with Self air set, flashlight and high boot. It took about an hour to go to and back from the RCIC room. Usually this takes only 10 minutes but at that time, there were still concerns of aftershocks and tsunami and putting on/off the self air set took extra time. In RCIC room, there was a water puddle and itâ€s depth was about the height of the boots. Faint metallic sound was heard but the operator was not able to check the rotating part. He returned to the MCR but was not able to determine whether RCIC was operating or not. Since PHS was not functioning, he reported the situation after getting back to the MCR (Reactor 2)

events.name: Water puddle in RCIC increased
events.description: Then at 2:00, the operator went there again. Water puddle increased and the operating status of RCIC was not able to see in the RCIC room. The operator determined RCIC was in operation by checking reactor pressure and RCIC discharge pressure at the instrument rack of RCIC and RCIC discharge pressure was high. After he reported this after returning to the MCR then reported to the site emergency response headquarters at 2:55. (Reactor 2)

events.name: METI order to manual Vent
events.description: There was an order of The Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry to implement the Vent based on the laws and ordinances (manual Vent). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Cable connection between P/C at Reactor 2 and high-voltage power supply vehicle completed
events.description: Cable connection between the primary side of P/C at Reactor 2 and high-voltage power supply vehicle was completed. Power was supplied just short of the SLC pump. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 RCIC Manually Started
events.description: Manually started up Reactor Core Isolation Cooling System (hereinafter RCIC). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 Shutdown RCIC
events.description: Shut down RCIC (High Reactor water level). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 confirmed uncritical
events.description: Confirmed uncritical on Reactor (Reactor 2)

events.name: Manually started RCIC
events.description: Manually started RCIC (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 RCIC shutdown
events.description: RCIC shut down (High Reactor water level). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 cable connections completed
events.description: Cable connection between the primary side of the P/C at Reactor 2 and the high voltage power supply vehicle was completed. Power was supplied just short of the SLC pump (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 manually started RCIC
events.description: Manually started up RCIC. (Reactor 2)

events.name: AC Power Lost
events.description: Lost all AC power sources (Reactor 2)

events.name: Opened valves of RHR
events.description: Taking the radiation level of Reactor 1 into consideration, before the radiation getting higher, in order to establish water injection line for alternative method by way of Residual Heat Reduction System, open the valves of Residual Heat Removal System manually in the turbine and reactor building, in the darkness, and secure the situation where water injection is possible after decompression of reactor (below 0.69MPa). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Confirmed damage of Power Panel - Start water injection
events.description: Restoration Team of Power Station Emergency Response Team has confirmed status of submergence and damage of Power Panel (High Voltage Clad Switch Gear, Power Center) and as a result of insulation resistance test, confirmed one of the power center was alive and start examination of water injection by using Control Rod Drive System(â€CRDâ€?) and Standby Liquid Control System(â€SLCâ€?), where high pressure water injection is possible, after power restoration to power center by power supply vehicle. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Consider injecting water using Fire Protection System
events.description: Start examination of using alternative method of water injection (Fire Protection System(â€FPâ€?), Feed Water Make-up System and Containment Vessel Cooling System), which are installed under Accident Management Plan(â€AP) and using fire engine with water from fire protection pool which was installed as a lesson of Chuetu-Oki Earthquake. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Prepare AM Manual and confirm water injection into reactor
events.description: In the Main Control Room, to secure alternative method of water injection, prepare AM manual on the Chief Unit Operatorâ€s desk and conduct confirmation of water injection line into the reactor. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Temporary Lighting Turned On
events.description: Temporary lighting was turned on in the main control room. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Risk water level reach Top of Active Fuel
events.description: Reported the risk that the water level may reach to Top of Active fuel (hereinafter TAF) because of uncertain Reactor water level and enable to check the condition of injecting water by RCIC to the Reactor. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Water level gauge confirms not reaching TAF
events.description: Water level gauge of the reactor has turned out and as its reading was Top of Active Fuel(â€TAFâ€?) +3400mm, confirmed not reaching TAF. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Confirm D/W pressure
events.description: At 11:25 PM, we could confirm the D/W pressure (0.141MPa abs) (Reactor 2)

events.name: Confirm D/W pressure may have exceeded 600kPa abs
events.description: At 12:06 AM on March 12, we confirmed that D/W pressure for Reactor 1 may have exceeded 600kPa abs. We started the actual work for Vent. At that time, as for Reactor 2, we checked from the drawings of valves whether we could manually open valves required for Vent and whether we could attach the jig and force the valve open. Based on the result, the piping and instrumentation diagram, AM operation procedure and the Vent procedure for Reactor 1, we confirmed the operation procedure of valves for Vent (PCV vent valve (MO valve) can be opened manually S/C vent valve (AO valve) cannot be opened manually) and prepared the Vent procedure. We also checked the places of valves for Vent using the valve check sheet. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Confirmed RCIC operating
events.description: Confirmed RCIC is under operation. (Reactor 2)

events.name: GM ordered to prepare operation of vent
events.description: General Manager of the power station ordered to prepare the operation of vent. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Water injection by RCIC continued
events.description: Water injection to the Reactor by RCIC continued. D/W pressure was stable at 200ïœ300kPaabs. As we expected that sooner or later we have to do Vent, we began preparation for the venting line-up together with Reactor 3. As the dose at the field site was low, we decided to open valves for Vent, other than the rupture disk. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Opened PCV vent valve 25%
events.description: At 8:10 AM, opened PCV vent valve (MO valve) by 25% per the operation procedure. (Reactor 2)

events.name: GM ordered to start Vent operation
events.description: General Manager of Power Station ordered to start Vent operation. (Reactor 2)

events.name: D/W pressure lower than working pressure of rupture disk
events.description: At 11:00 AM, we excited the solenoid for S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large by a small generator for the temporary lighting at the Main Control Room and opened S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large. We made up the vent line other than the rupture disk. ïŒD/W pressure was lower than the working pressure of the rupture disk (427kPa gauge), so Vent hadnâ€t yet occurred. We kept the vent valves open and continued monitoring D/W pressure.ïŒ‰ (Reactor 2)

events.name: Vent line composition completed except for rupture disc
events.description: Vent line composition was completed except for rupture disc. (Reactor 2)

events.name: GM ordered to prepare to use sea water
events.description: General Manager of Power Station ordered to prepare to use sea water. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Shift operators departed for R/B
events.description: In order to manually open PCV vent valve (MO valve), shift operators wore necessary equipments such as the self-contained breathing apparatus, brought the flashlight and departed for R/B. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Operations impacted by the explosion
events.description: Because of the explosion, the excitation of the solenoid for S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large turned off and the S/C vent valve closed. We had to do the venting line-up again. After the explosion, workers other than shift operators at the Main Control Room suspended all works and evacuated to the main anti-earthquake building. As we had to confirm the workersâ€ safety and the status of the field site, we couldnâ€t resume work for a while. D/W pressure was around 450kPa abs, stable below the Vent pressure. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 - S/C incapable of open
events.description: The large valve of suppression chamber became (hereinafter â€S/Câ€?) â€Closeâ€? because of the explosion of building of Reactor 3. Incapable of â€Openâ€? was confirmed. Prepared water injection line was not available because of breakage of the fire engine and the hose. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor 2 Pressure
events.description: S/C Temperature was 149.3â„ and S/C pressure was 486Pa even if the SR valve was opened, there was a possibility of pressure reduction difficulty as the steam will not be condensed, decided after conducting Containment Vessel Vent (â€Ventâ€?), then open the SR valve and water injection will be started. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Restarted composing line
events.description: Recommencement of composing line of injecting seawater including fire engine. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Water level of reactor in down trend
events.description: At 13:18 the water level of reactor was in the down trend. At 13:25 Determined lose of RCIC function. Estimated from the current situation, reaching TAF will be at around 16:30. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reported injecting seawater to Reactor
events.description: As Reactor water level was downward trend , reported to start preparation work such as injecting seawater to the Reactor immediately to the authorities. (Reactor 2)

events.name: RCIC function lost
events.description: As Reactor water level is decreasing, the RCIC function seems to be lost, judged Article15, clause1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness occurred (Lost Reactor Cooling Function) , and reported to the authorities at 1:38 pm. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Connected fire engine to FP
events.description: Connected to FP by fire engine. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Aftershocks affected work and evacuation
events.description: From after 15PM to after 16PM due to the aftershocks centered in offshore of Fukushima Prefecture, work was conducted with difficulties of suspension of work and evacuation. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reported evaluated TAF reaching time - 4:30 pm
events.description: Evaluated TAF reaching time is 4:30 pm, reported it to the authorities. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Attempted to open S/C vent valve
events.description: After the instruction for evacuation was lifted, at 4:00 PM, we tried to open S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Gathered batteries from parking lot and carried to control room
events.description: At around 16:00ïŒas it was foreseeable taking time until opening vent valve, changed priority on decompression of reactor by opening SR valve. The station manger also directed to conduct opening vent valve in parallel. Under the lack of power, battery was necessary to open the SR valve. Gathered batteries out from the cars and carried to main control room and connected to the electricity cable, however, as the power voltage was lacking, add batteries, try operating several SR valves (Reactor 2)

events.name: Air pressure from compressor insufficient to open S/C vent valve
events.description: At 4:20 PM, as the air pressure from the compressor was insufficient, we couldnâ€t open. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Started fire engine and prepared to start water injection
events.description: At around 16:30 started fire engine and prepared for the readiness to start water injection when decompression of reactor. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Initiated operation to reduce reactor pressure
events.description: Started operation for reducing Reactor pressure, and reported to start injecting seawater using fire protection system to authorities. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor pressure 6.998MPa
events.description: Reactor pressure 6.998MPa (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor water level reached TAF
events.description: Reactor water level reached TAF. Reported it to the authorities at 5:25 pm. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Initiated reactor depressurization
events.description: Started decompression of the reactor. Time was consumed as the temperature and pressure of S/C was high and difficult condition for condensation. "Started Reactor depressurization (Reactor pressure 5.4MPa=>7:03 pm 0.63 MPa )." (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor pressure 6.075MPa
events.description: Reactor pressure 6.075MPa (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor fuel exposed to air
events.description: Reactor water level reached TAF-3,700mm. Judge the fuel was exposed to air. Reported to the authorities at (Reactor 2)

events.name: Unable to open both S/C valves
events.description: As there was no change on D/W pressure, at 6:35 PM, we tried to open not only S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large but also S/C vent valve (AO valve)-small to restore the vent line. We presumed that we couldnâ€t open S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large because of malfunction of solenoid. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Reactor pressure 0.63MPa
events.description: Reactor pressure 0.63MPa (Reactor 2)

events.name: Fire engines rotated due to high radiation
events.description: Radiation at site was high and confirmation of operating status of fire engines was forced in rotation, at 19:20, confirmed fire engine which was used for water injection was stopped due to the shortage of fuel (Reactor 2)

events.name: Initiated injection to Reactor from Fire Protection System by fire engine
events.description: After fueling, started water injection into the reactor by using FP line by fire engine(at 19:54, 19:57 started respectively). Started injecting seawater to the Reactor from Fire Protection System by fire engine (started up at 7:54 pm and 7:57) (Reactor 2)

events.name: Slightly open S/C vent valve
events.description: At 9:00 PM, we could slightly open S/C vent valve (AO valve)-small. We established the venting line-up other than the rupture disk. ïŒD/W pressure was lower than the working pressure of the rupture disk (427kPa gauge), so Vent hadnâ€t yet occurred. We kept the vent valves open and continued monitoring D/W pressure.ïŒ‰ (Reactor 2)

events.name: Opened 2 Safety Release Valves
events.description: Opened 2 Safety Release Valves (hereinafter SRV) and confirmed recovering of water level. Reported it to the authorities at 9:34 pm (as of 9:30 pm Reactor water level=TAF-3,000mm). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Pressure of S/C and D/W not unified
events.description: At 10:50 PM - As Dry Well (hereinafter D/W) pressure exceeded maximum usage pressure 427kPa gage, it was judged to specific issue (RPV pressure abnormally raised) based on Article15, clause1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness occurred, and reported to the authorities at 11:39 pm. D/W pressure was in upward trend whereas S/C pressure was stable around 300ïœ400kPa abs. The pressure was not unified. As S/C pressure was lower than the working pressure of the rupture disk and D/W pressure increased, we decided to open D/W vent valve (AO valve)-small to do Vent. (Reactor 2)

events.name: S/C pressure lower than rupture disk operation pressure
events.description: As the pressure at S/C side was lower than working pressure of the rupture disk and the pressure at D/W side was raising, decided measure of vent operation with opening small valve of D/W vent. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Vent line composition completed except for rupture disc
events.description: Operated to open the small valve of D/W vent valve (AO valve). Vent line composition except for rupture disc was completed (confirmed the valve was closed few minutes later). (Reactor 2)

events.name: Completed preparation of venting line-up other than the rupture disk
events.description: At 12:02 AM on March 15, we finished preparation of the venting line-up other than the rupture disk. A few minutes later, we confirmed that the rupture disk was closed. ïŒD/W pressure did not go down from 750kPa abs. After that, D/W pressure was stable but high.ïŒ‰ (Reactor 2)

events.name: Unable to depressurize D/W pressure sufficiently
events.description: As D/W pressure exceeded designed maximum usage pressure, tried to operate to reduce pressure and injecting water to the Reactor. But the situation was not depressurized sufficiently. Reported it to the authorities at 4:17 am. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Explosion
events.description: At 6:00ïœ6:10, A large impulsive sound occurred around suppression chamber. S/C. The measured S/C pressure went down to 0MPaabs. Other than TEPCO employees and workers required for plant supervision and temporary restoration work, we temporarily evacuated to Fukushima Daini. 650 persons moved to Fukushima Daini. 70 persons stayed at the power station headquarters. (Reactor 2)

events.name: D/W pressure 730kPa abs
events.description: D/W pressure (730kPa abs(7:20) (Reactor 2)

events.name: Confirmed decrease in D/W pressure
events.description: Shift operators periodically went to the Main Control Room to log D/W pressure etc. At 11:25 AM, we confirmed decrease in D/W pressure 730kPa abs (7:20) 155kPa abs (11:25) (Reactor 2)

events.name: Confirmed white smoke (steam) rising out of 5th floor of Reactor Building
events.description: Confirmed white smoke (seems steam) rising out from the wall around 5th floor of Reactor Building, reported to the authorities at 9:18pm. (Reactor 2)

events.name: Formed water supply line toward Reactor 2 and Reactor 3
events.description: Since the vertical shaft of reversing valve was not available, we placed good fire engines around Shallow Draft Quay and re-arranged hoses in order to take seawater directly from sea and inject it to the reactor. By connecting 2 fire engines in series, we formed the water supply line toward both Reactor 2 and 3. (Reactor 2, Reactor 3)

events.name: Reactor 3 EDGs activated
events.description: Emergency diesel generators activated automatically (Reactor 3)

events.name: Reactor 3 subcritical
events.description: It was confirmed that the reactor was subcritical (Reactor 3)

events.name: Reactor 3 RCIC activated manually
events.description: Reactor Core Isolation Cooling System (hereinafter called â€RCICâ€?) activated manually (Reactor 3)

events.name: Reactor 3 RCIC tripped
events.description: RCIC tripped (as the reactor water level was high) (Reactor 3)

events.name: RCIC Manually started
events.description: At 16:03, RCIC was manually started, parameters like discharge pressure and rotating speed were confirmed in MCR. Operating status was monitored and made HPCI start up ready. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Radiation dose increase
events.description: Increase of the radiation dose was confirmed (Near the main gate, 0.069ÎŒSv/h,) (Reactor 3)

events.name: Reactor pressure dropped below fire engines jet force
events.description: The reactor pressure went below the fire enginesâ€ jet force, which allowed us to start alternative water injection by fire engines (Reactor 3)

events.name: RCIC tripped
events.description: RCIC tripped (Reactor 3)

events.name: Unable to restart water injection by existing facilities
events.description: We tried to restart water injection by existing cooling facilities, but could not. We tried water injection by diesel powered fire-extinguishing pumps, but could not because the reactor pressure was as high as approximately 4MPa. We tried to reboot HPCI, but could not due to the lack of batteries. We tried water injection through RCIC by confirming the situation in RCIC operation room, but could not reboot it. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Fire engines unable to respond
events.description: Fire engines in the site were called but could not arrive, because they were all being used for water injection to Reactor 1. Since tsunami occurred, the traffic between Reactor 3 and Reactor 5/6 had been disrupted due to the damage of the road and rubbles caused by tsunami. However, as restoration work such as road leveling with sandbags and removal of rubbles progressed, the restored traffic between Reactor 3 and Reactor 5/6 allowed us to bring the fire engines from Reactor 5/6. Also, a fire engine prepared as a backup facility for the emergency of Fukushima Daini moved to Fukushima Daiichi. Fire engines for water injection were lined up, sourcing freshwater from fire cistern. In order to inject water by fire engines, it was necessary to decrease the reactor pressure by operating Safety Relief Valve (S/R Valve), but S/R Valve was not able to be operated because batteries had run out. Since batteries in the site were already collected for the restoration of indicators, Reactor 1 and 2, there were no extra batteries in the site. Therefore, we removed and gathered batteries from employeesâ€ car and connected them to indicators of Main Control Room. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Power restoration work unable to be completed
events.description: Since the previous day we continued power restoration work via Power Center in order to restore Boric Acid Injection System that was capable of high pressure water injection, but the work was not successfully progressed due to the interruption of the work and evacuation caused by earthquakes from time to time and bad work environment (dark place, obstacles scattered and manhole covers lost). As a result, the restoration was not completed. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Freshwater near fire cisterns ran out
events.description: Since freshwater of near fire cisterns ran out at 12:20 pm, we started to change the water supply line in order to use seawater in the vertical shaft of reversing valve. We had been well prepared for quick switching, but we were forced to suspend the work by the evacuation order caused by aftershocks. (Reactor 3)

events.name: HPCI activated automatically
events.description: High Pressure Core Injection System (hereinafter called â€HPCIâ€?) activated automatically (as the reactor water level was low) (Reactor 3)

events.name: Injection of sea water into the reactor started
events.description: Injection of sea water into the reactor through the fire extinction system started (Reactor 3)

events.name: Plant manager ordered to prepare for vent of PCV
events.description: Plant manager ordered to prepare for the vent of primary containment vessel (hereinafter called â€ventâ€?) (Reactor 3)

events.name: Started considering vent procedures
events.description: At the Main Control Room, at 9:00 PM, we started considering Vent procedures. We checked the sequence and places of valves and wrote on the whiteboard. The generation team of the power station emergency response headquarters (â€PSERâ€?) completed the Vent procedure manual for Reactor 1. Based on that Vent procedure manual for Reactor 1 and the accident management procedure manual for Reactor 3, generation team considered the Vent procedure manual for Reactor 3 together with the restoration team. We notified the Vent procedure manual to the Main Control Room. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Terminated injection of fresh water
events.description: Injection of fresh water terminated (Reactor 3)

events.name: Large valve of S/C vent opened (AO valve)
events.description: The large valve of S/C vent valve (AO valve) was opened (as the air tank for the actuation was exchanged) (Reactor 3)

events.name: HPCI stopped
events.description: HPCI stopped (Reactor 3)

events.name: Water level reached top of active fuel
events.description: As it was determined that the water level reached to the top of active fuel (hereinafter called â€TAFâ€?) at 4:15 am, it was informed to the government offices etc. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Excited solenoid using small generator to open S/C vent valve
events.description: At 4:50 AM, in order to open S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large, we excited the solenoid using a small generator for the temporary lighting at the Main Control Room. The shift operator checked the indicator of the valve at the Torus Room. As the indicator showed â€closedâ€?, we determined that the valve was completely closed. Inside the Torus Room was very hot because of the Reactor steam flow from the safety relief valve to S/C (S/C is below the Torus Room). There was no lighting i.e. complete darkness. It was a tough working environment. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Determined loss of RCIC
events.description: It was determined that a specific incident stipulated in article 15, clause 1 of Act on Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness (loss of reactor cooling function) occurred as the injection of water by RCIC was impossible, and it was informed to the government offices etc. at 5:58 am (Reactor 3)

events.name: Station manager instructed to prepare for press conference
events.description: At 5:15 AM, Station Manager instructed to complete the venting line-up other than the rupture disk and prepare for the press release. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Changed air tank and attempted to open S/C vent valve
events.description: At 5:23 AM as the solenoid for S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large was excited but the S/C vent valve was closed, we determined that we had to change the air tank. After that, we changed the air tank and opened the S/C vent valve. (Reactor 3)

events.name: RCIC injection impossible
events.description: Special Measures Concerning Nuclear Emergency Preparedness (loss of reactor cooling function) occurred as the injection of water by RCIC was impossible, and it was informed to the government offices etc (Reactor 3)

events.name: Initiated spray inside the PCV
events.description: Spray inside the primary containment vessel started, and it was informed to the government offices etc. at 7:56 am (Reactor 3)

events.name: Manually opened PCV vent valve to 15%
events.description: At 8:35 AM, we manually opened the vent valve (MO valve) to 15% per the procedure. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Configuration of vent line completed except for rupture disk
events.description: At 8:41AM, we finished the venting line-up. The pending was rupture of the rupture disk. By opening the large valve of the vent valve (AO valve) of the suppression chamber (hereinafter called â€S/Câ€?), the configuration of the vent line was completed except for the rupture disk. It was informed to the government offices etc. at 8:46 am (Reactor 3)

events.name: Rapid depressurization of reactor pressure by safety relief valve implemented
events.description: A rapid depressurization of the reactor pressure by safety relief valve was implemented (Reactor 3)

events.name: D/W trending pressure down
events.description: D/W pressure went down 0.637 MPa abs (9:10 AM) to 0.540 MPa abs (9:24 AM) (Reactor 3)

events.name: PSER determined that Vent was done around 9:20 AM.
events.description: At 9:24 AM, as D/W pressure went down 0.637 MPa abs (9:10 AM) to 0.540 MPa abs (9:24 AM), PSER determined that Vent was done around 9:20 AM. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Injection of fresh water and boric acid into reactor initiated
events.description: Injection of fresh water (with boric acid) into the reactor by fire truck through fire extinction system was started (Reactor 3)

events.name: Air tanks pressure in downward trend
events.description: At 9:28 AM, as the air tankâ€s pressure at S/C vent valve (AO valve) was in downward trend, we went to the field site to tighten the connecting parts. We confirmed air leakage and repaired. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Drop of drywell pressure caused by vent operation confirmed
events.description: Drop of drywell (hereinafter called â€D/Wâ€?) pressure caused by vent operation was confirmed. It was informed to the government offices that injection of water to the reactor through fire extinction system started (Reactor 3)

events.name: Plant Manager ordered to inject sea water
events.description: Plant Manager ordered to intend an injection of sea water (Reactor 3)

events.name: Requesting additional fire engines
events.description: We had been requesting several offices for the support of fire engines, but it was not impossible for such fire engines to directly approach the power station due to radioactivity and contamination in the site and bad condition of the road to the station. It took longer time for fire engines to arrive at the station because the drivers needed to be changed to the plant operators at Off-site Center or J-Village. We tried to take seawater accumulated at the basement of the turbine, Reactor 4 by breaking the entrance shutters of truck bay doors of the turbine building and moving fire engines to the place, but could not. Additionally, we examined the possibility of taking water from the discharge channel of Reactor 4 or the skill training centerâ€s pool, but that was not implemented. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Replaced air tank and opened S/C vent valve
events.description: At 11:17 AM, The close of large valve of S/C vent valve (AO valve) was confirmed (as the pressure of the air tank for the actuation dropped) We replaced the air tank and opened. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Unable to open and lock S/C vent valve at open position
events.description: At 12:30 PM, we confirmed that S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large was open. In order to open and lock S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large S/C at open position, we went to the Torus Room. As the temperature was high and there was vibration due to the operation of the safety relief valve, we could not open and lock. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Injection of sea water into reactor through the fire extinction system started
events.description: Injection of sea water into the reactor through the fire extinction system started (Reactor 3)

events.name: Observed 300mSv/h at north side airlock - 100 mSv at south side airlock
events.description: At 2:31 PM, we observed over 300mSv/h at the north side airlock, R/B (there was white gaseous substance inside) and 100mSv/h at the south side airlock. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Evacuated all operators to Reactor 4 side
events.description: At 3:28 PM, the dose at the Main Control Room of Reactor 3 side went up to 12mSv/h. Shift operators evacuated to Reactor 4 side. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Finished charging the temporary compressor
events.description: At 5:52 PM, we finished charging the temporary compressor. As dose was high, the restoration team of PSER brought the temporary compressor to the large equipments carry-in opening by a crane truck and connected to IA line. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Determined S/C vent valve opened due to reduction of D/W pressure
events.description: At 8:10 PM, we determined that S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large opened from the reduction of D/W pressure. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Ceased operation of fire engines in order to supply seawater to the vertical shaft
events.description: Since the remaining amount of seawater in the vertical shaft of revering valve became little at 1:10 am on March 14, we stopped the operation of fire engines in order to supply seawater to the vertical shaft. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Fire truck to supply sea water into reversing valve pit
events.description: As there were little sea water left to inject into the reactor, a fire truck was arranged to supply sea water into the reversing valve pit (Reactor 3)

events.name: D/W pressure in upward trend
events.description: From 2:00 AM (3-14) D/W pressure was in upward trend - We decided to open S/C vent valve (AO valve)-small. 0.265MPa abs - 2:00 AM 0.315MPa abs - 3:00 AM (Reactor 3)

events.name: Resumed injection of seawater
events.description: With regard to seawater injection to Reactor 3, we were able to resume injection at 3:20 am since we could take seawater by putting fire engines close to the vertical shaft of reversing valve and placing the nozzle of the hose at deeper spot. Additional fire engines arrived at the station early in the morning. In order to directly take seawater and supply it to the vertical shaft of reversing valve, we placed 2 fire engines at around Shallow Draft Quay and arranged the line for water supply. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Excited the solenoid
events.description: At 3:40 AM, we excited the solenoid. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Operation of Small (AO valve) of S/C vent valve
events.description: At 5:20 AM, we started operation to open S/C vent valve (AO valve)-small. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Confirmed small valve of the S/C valve opened
events.description: At 6:10 AM, we confirmed that the valve was open. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Injection of seawater from shallow draft quay into reversing valve pit started
events.description: We started supplying seawater from Shallow Draft Quay to the vertical shaft of reversing valve at 9:20 am. (Reactor 3)

events.name: 7 SDF Water Supply Vehicles requested as source of freshwater
events.description: 7 Water Supply Vehicles (each 5 tons) of Self Defense Force that were requested as the source of freshwater arrived at the station. We decided to use them to supply water to the vertical shaft of reversing valve and placed them at the shaft at 10:53 am. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Started Water Supply until Explosion
events.description: We started water supply, but stopped due to the explosion of the reactor building. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Restarted Seawater by Fire Engines
events.description: At approximately 4:30 pm, we restarted seawater injection by fire engines. Around 4:30 pm New injection line into the reactor was constructed by exchanging the fire truck and horse, and the injection of sea water restarted (Reactor 3)

events.name: Confirmed steam from upper side of reactor building
events.description: Steam floating at the upper side of the reactor building was confirmed, and it was informed to the government offices etc (Reactor 3)

events.name: Confirmed S/C valve closed - Unable to keep open
events.description: 16:00 - Confirmed closed - After this, because of loss of air pressure for S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large and loss of excitation of the solenoid at the air supply line, we couldnâ€t maintain the S/C vent valve open. Several times we operated the valve to open. 16:05 - Operated to open - After this, because of loss of air pressure for S/C vent valve (AO valve)-large and loss of excitation of the solenoid at the air supply line, we couldnâ€t maintain the S/C vent valve open. Several times we operated the valve to open. (Reactor 3)

events.name: Attempted to open S/C valve several times - Unable to keep open
